questions.text: Which of the following nerve does not innervate the muscles of gluteal region?
questions.solution:
The sciatic nerve does not innervate the muscles of the gluteal region.

It is the largest nerve of the body and is made up of L4 to S3 spinal nerves of sacral plexus. It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, inferior to the piriformis. It descends in the posterior thigh and divides into the tibial and common peroneal nerves proximal to the knee joint.

Tibial component of the sciatic nerve supplies:

  • Semimembranosus
  • Semitendinosus
  • Ischial part of adductor magnus
  • Long head of biceps femoris

The common fibular component of the sciatic nerve supplies short head of biceps femoris.

questions.text:
If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen

ESV: End-systolic volume

EDV: End-diastolic volume

choices.text: End diastolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.solution:
If the contractility of the heart is decreased, slope changes in the ESV pressure curve are seen. 

To answer this question, we will first understand the volume-pressure diagram and the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR) during cardiac cycle. 

Volume-pressure diagram during the cardiac cycle

The volume pressure diagram plots the changes in the pressure and volume in the left ventricle that occurs during the cardiac cycle. The x-axis shows the changes in ventricular volume, while the y-axis shows the changes in ventricular pressure.

It has the following phases.

Phase I- This phase is called the period of filling and extends between points A and B. Point A is at the end of systole when the ventricular volume is about 50 mL. This volume is called end-systolic volume. The pressure at this point is about 2 to 3 mm Hg. These volume and pressure go on increasing as the blood from the atrium flows to the ventricle during diastole. At the end of diastole, marked by point B, the ventricle will have a volume of around 120 mL. This volume is called end-diastolic volume. The pressure is slightly raised to 5-7mm Hg. 

Phase II- It is the phase of isovolumetric contraction, and extends between points B and C. At the end of diastole (point B), a slight increase in the ventricular pressure closes the mitral valve, and contraction starts. The ventricle contracts while both mitral and aortic valves are closed. Therefore, the pressure within the ventricle slowly rises without any changes in the volume. 

Phase III- It is the phase of ejection and extends between point C and point D. Point C is the place where the aortic valve opens. The pressure within the left ventricle rises slowly during isovolumetric contraction until it is sufficient to open the aortic valve. Once the aortic valve opens, blood within the left ventricle is ejected into the aorta. This decreases the volume of the left ventricle, while increasing the pressure within the ventricle.

Phase IV- It is the period of isovolumetric relaxation. It extends between points D and A. At the end of the ejection (Point D), the aortic valve closes. However, the ventricular relaxation continues despite closed aortic and mitral valves. Therefore, the ventricular pressure continues to fall while the volume remains the same. The ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and pressure of about 2 to 3 mm Hg

End-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR)

ESPVR is the maximum pressure that can be developed by the ventricle at the end-systolic volume. It is determined by the line intersecting the upper left corners of the loops. This line can be extended down to the x-axis. The slope of this line is called as ESPVR slope. 

Now coming to the question, when the contractility of the heart is decreased, the force of ejection decreases leading to decreased stroke volume, and increased end-systolic volume. Therefore, the volume-pressure diagram shifts to the right. If the diagram shifts to the right, then ESPVR also changes, leading to a change in the slope of the ESPVR curve.

Other options:

Options A and D- End diastolic volume and pressure curve (EDPVR) mainly assesses the compliance of the ventricle, rather than contractility. The slope of this curve increases when the compliance decreases, and vice versa.

Option C- ESPVR shifts to right with change in slope.

questions.text: Which metalloprotein is responsible for the metabolism of artificial flovours and additives ?
questions.solution:
Cytochrome P450 is involved in the metabolism of flavour/colour additives which are examples of xenobiotics.

Hydroxylation of xenobiotics is done by Cytochrome P450.The members of the cytochrome P450 family generate Fe = O3+. This is a powerful oxidant that participates in the reduction and neutralization of a broad range of xenobiotics via the two-electron reduction of O2.

Cytochrome p450 is a heme-containing monooxygenase. It is located mainly in the endoplasmic reticulum in the liver and intestine but is also found in the mitochondria in some tissues.  

Micro­somal cytochrome P450 in the endoplasmic reticulum of the liver detoxifies xenobiotics like drugs, carcinogens, and pesti­cides. The cytochrome P450 monooxygenase system hydroxylates these toxins, using NADPH as the source of reducing equivalents. The purpose is to activate or inactivate a drug or to make a toxic compound more soluble, thus facilitating excretion.

Mitochondrial cytochrome P450 systems are found in steroidogenic tissues such as the adrenal cortex, testis, ovary, and placenta and are concerned with the biosynthesis of steroid hormones and cholesterol.

Naturally occurring compounds in foods such as grapefruit also affect cytochrome P450. Grapefruit contains furanocoumarins, which inhibit cytochrome P450 and affect the metabolism of many drugs like statins, omeprazole, antihistamines and benzodiazepenes.

Related Pearl: Heme containing proteins

Protein Function
 Hemoglobin   Transport of oxygen in the blood
 Myoglobin   Storage of oxygen in muscle
 Cytochrome C   Involvement in the electron transport chain
 Cytochrome P450  Hydroxylation of xenobiotics
 Catalase  Degradation of hydrogen peroxide
 Tryptophan pyrrolase  Oxidation of tryptophan

questions.text: A 1-year-old child was diagnosed to have Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. What is this condition associated with?
questions.solution:
Kasabach–Merritt syndrome is associated with DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation). This syndrome is characterised by the following features:

  • Rapidly growing vascular tumour
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia
  • Consumptive coagulopathy

An unusual form of DIC occurs in association with giant hemangiomas. In this type, stasis and recurrent trauma to the fragile blood vessels cause thrombi to form within the neoplasm.

The image given below shows a reddish-blue lesion covering the lower part of the abdomen. It is a caverno-capillary haemangioma seen in Kasabach–Merritt syndrome.

questions.text:
Match the following images with the corresponding Streptococcal skin/soft tissue infection.

A - Cellulitis

B - Erysipelas

C - Impetigo

D - Myositis
questions.solution:
The images are matched as follows :

Column A (From the thumbnail image) Column B 
1 D - Myositis
2 C - Impetigo
3 

B - Erysipelas
4  A - Cellulitis

Myositis : 

Fulminant, invasive S. pyogenes infections with streptococcal toxic shock syndrome are characterized by shock, bacteremia, respiratory failure, and multiorgan failure. Death occurs in about 30% of patients. The infections tend to occur after minor trauma in otherwise healthy persons with several presentations of soft tissue infection. These include necrotizing fasciitis, myositis, and infections at other soft tissue sites.

Impetigo : 

Local infection of superficial layers of skin, especially in children, is called impetigo. It consists of superficial vesicles that break down and eroded areas whose denuded surface is covered with pus and later is encrusted. 

Erysipelas :

If the portal of entry of S. pyogenes, β-Hemolytic Group A Streptococci is the skin, erysipelas results. Lesions are raised and characteristically red. There is massive brawny edema and a rapidly advancing, sharply demarcated margin of infection.

Cellulitis :

Streptococcal cellulitis is an acute, rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues. It follows infection associated with mild trauma, burns, wounds, or surgical incisions. Pain, tenderness, swelling, and erythema occur. Cellulitis is differentiated from erysipelas by two clinical findings: In cellulitis, the lesion is not raised, and the line between the involved and uninvolved tissue is indistinct.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the emergency management of asthma does not act by bronchodilation?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone does not act by bronchodilation while all other drugs mentioned act by bronchodilation.

Mechanism of action of Corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to Beta-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of beta 2 receptor genes and hence increases responsiveness to beta-2 agonists. Beta-2 agonists, on the other hand, increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors.

Other options:

β2 selective agonists like salbutamol, terbutaline, salmeterol, formoterol, etc, cause relaxation of the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles by β2 receptor agonist action.

Ipratropium bromide acts by antagonizing muscarinic receptors in bronchial smooth muscle, thereby causing bronchodilation.

Theophyllines(e.g deriphylline) increases the effects of steroids by activating enzyme histone deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the primary health center with a history of snakebite. The area of the bite is painful and appears red and swollen. From his description, the snake that bit him had a triangular head with a V-shaped mark as shown in the image below. All of the following statements regarding this snake bite are true except?

choices.text: Death is due to shock and haemorrhage
Persistent bleeding from bite site is noticed
Bleeding and clotting time are prolonged

questions.solution:
From the patient's description and the image, the snake is most likely Russell's viper. The victims of Russell's viper may become oliguric within a few hours of the bite suggesting renal ischemia.

The Russell's viper has a flat and triangular head with a V-shaped mark, white in color, with the angle of the V pointing forwards. Along the back, it has three rows of diamond-shaped spots. Other points of identification include broad plates on its belly, the small scales on the head, and a shield beneath the tail divided into two rows. It is commonly found throughout India.

Russell's viper venom contains two proteases that activate the blood-clotting cascade. Though more than half the victims have minimal or no poisoning, few develop serious generalized poisoning. At the spot where venom is injected, the patient develops severe pain and the area around the bite becomes red and painful. Persistent bleeding from the bite site is a constant feature. Blisters begin to appear in some hours which progressively involves the entire limb. Skin temperature is raised. Intravascular hemolysis may lead to hemoglobinuria which progresses to renal failure.

Since the venom affects the blood-clotting cascade, the bleeding and clotting time are usually prolonged. Patients may develop hemorrhagic syndrome due to bleeding from various sites like gums, rectum, etc. Death is usually due to hemorrhagic shock.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with difficulty in breathing through the nose and epistaxis. On evaluation, he was diagnosed with a nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Which of the following is true regarding the disease?

choices.text: Blood supply is from the internal maxillary artery
Biopsy is the investigation of choice
Rhinolalia aperta is a clinical feature

questions.solution:
The blood supply of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is most commonly from the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery. 

Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx, commonly affecting young males. It originates from the fibrovascular stroma on the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity close to the area of the sphenopalatine foramen and the pterygoid base.

It is a histologically benign but locally aggressive tumor that grows at the back of the nasal cavity. Blood supply is most commonly from the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery or sphenopalatine artery. It encroaches by expanding into surrounding areas like the nasal cavity, sphenoidal sinus, pterygopalatine fossa, maxillary sinus, orbit, and cranial cavity.

Clinical features include:

  1. Difficulty breathing through the nose
  2. Epistaxis
  3. Rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech)
  4. Bulging of the soft palate 
  5. Underdeveloped secondary sexual characters

Tumour diagnosis is based on the characteristic findings on CT, MRI, and angiography. Biopsy should not be undertaken as it is a highly vascular tumour and can lead to severe bleeding.

Endoscopic resection is preferred in tumours that are limited to nasal cavity, nasopharynx, sphenoid sinus and pterygopalatine fossa. Further extensions are managed with excision of the tumor by: 

  • Wilson’s trans-palatal approach
  • Lateral rhinotomy

Radiation can be used in cases of intracranial extension.

questions.text: Retinoscopy done at 1 m without cycloplegia exhibits ‘’with movement.’’ All of the following refractive errors are possible except __________.
questions.solution:
A patient with 1 D myopia would exhibit no movement of red reflex when retinoscopy is done from a distance of 1m without cycloplegia.

Interpretation of retinoscopy done at 1m without cycloplegia:

No movement - myopia of 1D.
With movement - emmetropia, hypermetropia, myopia less than 1D.
Against movement - myopia more than 1D.

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking during pregnancy and low birth weight is being carried out. It involves obtaining smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The study of choice is a prospective cohort study.
A prospective cohort study is a study in which the outcome has not yet occurred at the time that the investigations begin. They begin in the present and continue into the future.
This study is a prospective cohort study because the subjects (pregnant women) were categorized on the basis of exposure or lack of exposure to a risk factor -smoking during pregnancy. They were followed to determine if the outcome- the low birth weight of the babies occurred or not.
The design of a prospective cohort is shown below.
A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before the investigations and study is undertaken. An example would be if the charts in a hospital from the previous year were reviewed, and mothers classified as smokers or nonsmokers based on records. The records are then followed through time and then the birth weight of the children in both groups are compared. It is also called a historical cohort study, a prospective study in retrospect, or a non-concurrent prospective study.
In a case-control study of the same, low birth weight infants would be selected as the cases and normal birth weight babies as the controls. The frequency of maternal smoking would then be compared in the two groups.
In cross-sectional studies, exposure and outcome are measured at the same point in time.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is positive for SARS-COV-2. A total of 30 people have been in contact with the patient and show no symptoms or signs of COVID-19. What is the time duration for which they must be quarantined?
questions.solution:
Quarantine is the limitation in freedom of movement of healthy contacts of cases, who have been exposed for a period that lasts as much as the maximal incubation period of the disease.

  • It is a primary level of prevention, under specific protection.
  • Types of quarantine
    • Absolute: complete limitation of movement
    • Modified: selective partial limitation of movement
    • Segregation: observation of a group of persons in a population after separation.
Mild Moderate Severe

Fever

URTI

Pneumonia with no signs of severe disease

(RR ≥ 24 SpO2 <94%)

Respiratory distress

(RR ≥ 30 SpO2 <90%)
Admit to COVID Care Centre/Home Quarantine Admit to Dedicated COVID Health Centre (DCHC) Admit to Dedicated COVID Hospital

Symptomatic Management

Can consider HCQ for those having high-risk features for severe disease

Oxygen: Target 92-96 % SpO2

Awake proning (if hypoxia with >4L O2)

Daily monitoring(CBC and RFT, LFT, Absolute lymphocyte count, ECG )

48 hourly Monitoring(CRP, D- dimer & Ferritin)


Tab HCQ 400mg BD x1 Day, followed by 400mg OD x4 Days

Anticoagulation (UFH or LMWH)
Enoxaparin 40mg SC OD

IV Methylprednisolone 0.5 to 1mg/kg for 3-5 days

Investigational therapies: Convalescent Plasma 200ml/day for every 24 hours;
Inj.Remdesivir - (not recommended by WHO)

CPAP or NIV

Intubation if needed

Prone ventilation considered in refractory hypoxemia

IV Methylprednisolone 1 to 2mg/kg/day for 7 days

High prophylactic dose of Anticoagulation (UFH or LMWH) Enoxaparin 40mg SC BD

Sepsis/ Septic Shock: managed according to their protocol

Sedation or Nutrition therapy


Investigational therapies:
Inj.Tocilizumab 8mg/kg one dose, repeated after 12 to 24 hour if no improvement occurs with the first dose.

questions.text: What is the name of the program whose logo is depicted below?

choices.text: Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment
Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission

questions.solution:
The image shows the logo of the Prime Minister’s Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment (POSHAN) Abhiyaan.

POSHAN Abhiyaan /National Nutrition Mission( NNM) is a flagship program of the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD), with a goal to achieve an improvement in the nutritional status of children in the first 1000 days of life, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. This program was implemented in March 2018.

NNM targets to reduce stunting, underweight, and low birth weight by 2% per annum. The target for the reduction in anemia among young children, and adolescent girls is 3% per annum. The four pillars of POSHAN are:

  1. Ensuring access to quality services.
  2. Ensuring convergence of multiple programs and schemes
  3. Leveraging technology (ICDS-CAS)
  4. Jan Andolan.

 The following image depicts the targets of this mission:

 

The logo of Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) is given below:

 

The logo of Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission (PPTCT):

 

The logo of Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (JSSK):

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cell/ microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical features are suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The drug of choice in this patient is cefotaxime.

SBP is characterized by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. 

In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. 

Diagnosis is by paracentesis and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal pathogenic organisms.

Management is mainly by third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime. Albumin infusion can be given as it decreases the risk of renal failure and improves patient survival. Early diagnosis and treatment improve the prognosis. In patients who have had an episode of SBP and recovered, once-weekly administration of antibiotics is used as prophylaxis for recurrent SBP.

questions.text: The medial medullary syndrome is associated with the involvement of
questions.solution:
The medial medullary syndrome (Dejerine syndrome) occurs due to the involvement of vertebral artery, anterior spinal artery, or basilar artery.

Other options:

  • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) involvement can cause lateral inferior pontine syndrome (AICA syndrome)
  • Posterior cerebral artery (PCA): The infarction in the distribution of the penetrating branches of PCA can cause Weber’s syndrome.
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA): involvement can cause the lateral medullary syndrome of Wallenberg.

Medial medullary syndrome:

  • Ipsilateral manifestation: Paralysis with atrophy of one-half half the tongue due to the involvement of the ipsilateral XII nerve.
  • Contralateral manifestation: Paralysis of arm and leg, sparing face; impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense over one-half the body due to the involvement of the contralateral pyramidal tract and medial lemniscus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented with nausea, vomiting, and constipation. He also has excess thirst and polyuria. On examination, he has an altered mental state. His past medical history is significant for lung cancer, which is now in remission.  His blood reports reveal elevated serum calcium levels and low serum parathyroid hormone. What is the most common type of underlying lung cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts the symptoms of hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome in association with underlying squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Hypercalcemia results from ectopic production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) or PTH-related peptides. It is the most common life-threatening metabolic complication of malignancy, primarily occurring with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Clinical manifestation of hypercalcemia:

  • Renal - polyuria, polydipsia, nephrolithiasis
  • Central nervous system - lethargy, altered mental status, stupor, coma
  • Gastrointestinal - Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, peptic ulcer disease, pancreatitis
  • Cardiac - bradycardia, AV block, short QT interval
  • Skeletal - bone pain, pathological fractures

Treatment:

  1. Volume expansion by intravenous normal saline (4-6L)
  2. Intravenous Bisphosphonates (Zoledronic acid, pamidronate)
  3. Others - Denosumab, gallium nitrate, steroids.

Paraneoplastic syndromes - may be the presenting finding or the first sign of recurrence of malignancy.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with Lung cancer:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
  • Hypercalcemia
Small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) 
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Eaton- Lambert syndrome
  • Retinal blindness
Adenocarcinoma 
  • Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)
  •  Clubbing

questions.text: A patient with marfanoid habitus, hyperparathyroidism, and neuromas of the tongue presents with a cervical mass.  The most likely cause of the cervical mass is_______.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is medullary carcinoma of the thyroid which occurs in the setting of MEN 2B.

Medullary carcinoma is seen in both in MEN 2A and 2B. The RET gene is abnormally activated. In Hirschsprung disease, it is deactivated.

MEN 2B: It is characterized by multiple mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid appearance, medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, gastrointestinal ganglioneuromatosis, and thickened corneal nerves. This rare syndrome is inherited in an autosomal-dominant pattern.

Medullary carcinomas arising in the context of MEN-2B are generally more aggressive and metastasize more frequently.

MEN syndromes:

  • The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases, resulting in proliferative lesions (hyperplasia, adenomas, and carcinomas) of multiple endocrine organs.
  • Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors.
  • Tumors arise in multiple endocrine organs, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times).
MEN1 MEN 2 (previously MEN2A) MEN 3 (previously MEN 2B) MEN 4
Wermer's Syndrome Sipple's Syndrome Mucosal neuromata with endocrine tumors due to mutation in CDKN1B.
  • Parathyroid tumors
  • Pituitary tumors
  • Pancreas tumors
  • Parathyroid tumors
  • Medullary thyroid Carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Ganglioneuromatosis

Similar to MEN 1 plus

  • Reproductive organ tumors (e.g. testicular tumors, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma)
  • Adrenal + Renal tumors

questions.text: A 25-year-old morbidly obese male patient presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain and urinary disturbances. His urine microscopy shows the following type of crystals and an ultrasound of the kidney revealed a renal stone of size 2.5 cm. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Urine microscopy shows hexagonal crystals, typical of cystine stones that are radio-opaque (due to high sulfur content). The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size 2.5 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

PCNL is the treatment of choice for large renal stones of a diameter more than 2cm. PCNL is indicated in the following types of renal calculi:

  • Staghorn calculi
  • Multiple stones
  • Proximal ureteral stone: >1 cm
  • Morbidly obese individuals in whom ESWL is contraindicated

Technique: Endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique and stones are removed.

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:

  • Haemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma
  • Perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant
  • Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track

Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy: 

ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones which are are often multiple, and very hard are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Other stones that are difficult to disintegrate by ESWL include cystine, brushite, and calcium oxalate monohydrate stones.

ESWL is only 45-60% efficacious in the treatment of large stones. Also, it causes frequent complications including pain, hydronephrosis, fever, and occasional urosepsis, due to difficulties in the passage of stone particles, especially in cases of insufficient disintegration.

Complications: Infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma. 

Contraindications: Obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Note:

Stone fragments collecting in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse  (a german word, which means 'street of stones'). The most common site of the column of stone fragments obstruction is the distal ureter, followed by the proximal ureter and mid ureter.The postoperative image is attached below.

 

Ureteroscopic removal:

Semi-rigid ureteroscopes are frequently used to directly visualise ureteric calculi. Advances in the design of ureterorenoscopy have rendered the entire urinary tract accessible to endoscopic examination.  Stones can also be fragmented using mechanical disintegration using the lithoclast.

These are generally preferred for stones <6mm and specifically those present in the distal ureter. 

The most significant complications relate to injury to the ureteric mucosa or wall and include ureteric perforation and extravasation, avulsion of the ureter and ureteric stricture.

The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy. 

 

Open surgery:

A longstanding obstructing calculus can result in chronic inflammatory change in the kidney. Open surgeries are generally indicated for xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Generally, in such cases, a subcapsular nephrectomy is performed. 

Also, in extremely rare cases where both PCNL and ESWL are contraindicated, one might resort to take up the patient for open/laparascopic surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and severe non-bilious vomiting. He was treated for upper abdominal pain 5 weeks ago.  CT scan reveals a pancreatic pseudocyst of size 8 cm in close proximity to the stomach with secondary pressure effects.  What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient would be to perform a cystogastrostomy since the size of the tumor is greater than 6 cm and in close proximity to the stomach.

Interventions in pseudocyst are required when:

  • Complicated by infection
  • Presence of a mass effect 
  • Diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm
  • Recurrence following the previous resection

Endoscopic drainage is usually curative. 

Feature

Treatment approach

Close contact (<1 cm) with the stomach

Transgastric drainage

Close contact (<1 cm) with the duodenum

Transduodenal drainage

Communicating with the main pancreatic duct

Transpapillary drainage

Pancreatic duct stricture associated with a pancreatic pseudocyst

Endoscopic dilation and stent placement

Surgical drainage is done if endoscopy is contraindicated or has failed.

In this cystogastrostomy, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.

The image shows the procedure involved in cystogastrostomy.

Cystoduodenostomy is done when pseudocyst is adjacent to the duodenum, or concern about disrupting pancreatic ductal entry into the duodenum.

Roux-en-Y Cystojejunostomy is generally done for cysts that are neither in close proximity to the stomach and nor to the duodenum. This is generally preferred as the last resort as it is associated with a lot of complications. 

Percutaneous drainage to the exterior under radiological guidance is associated with a high recurrence rate and high incidence of pancreatic-cutaneous fistula. Hence, it is not usually done.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought into casualty with a history of swelling in the right groin for the past 6 months. On examination, a reducible hernia is present in the right groin with no features of strangulation. What is the next step in the management of the patient?

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and do elective surgery later
Reduce the swelling and later observe

questions.solution:
As this patient is asymptomatic now and has no features of obstruction or strangulation and is a reducible hernia, the best option is to reduce the swelling and do elective surgery later.

Emergency Surgery should be offerred ,if there are features of

  • strangulation
  • bowel obstruction 
  • bowel infarction

Elective surgery should be given for

  • all femoral hernias which has high risk of strangulation,
  • increasing size of the swelling,
  • increasing difficulty in reduction of the swelling 
  • young patients who might have high risk of complications later in life.

Note:

Any patient who presents with acute pain in a hernia, particularly if irreducible, should be offered surgery .

In most irreducible hernia cases , after giving adequate analgesia the hernia will reduce due to muscle relaxation.

In the elderly, if the hernia is asymptomatic, small in size,can be reduced easily and is not causing anxiety then observation alone is enough.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female patient presents with abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. She had a history of abdominal hysterectomy 2 years back. On examination, abdomen auscultation revealed hyperechoic bowel sounds. Investigations showed air within the biliary tree. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing clinical features of intestinal obstruction along with radiographic features of pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree) is suggestive of a diagnosis of gallstone ileus.

Gallstone ileus is a condition that occurs secondary to the erosion of the gallbladder wall. This erosion causes a fistula to the duodenum. Through this, a large gallstone can pass from the gallbladder to the duodenum. The most common site of impaction of the gallstone is the distal ileum, where it may cause intestinal obstruction.

Patients present with features of mechanical small bowel obstruction such as continuous or intermittent pain abdomen, bilious vomiting, and hyperechoic bowel sounds.

Rigler’s triad is a characteristic radiological feature seen in gallstone ileus and consists of:

  • Pneumobilia - air present in the intestine passes into the biliary tree through the fistula
  • Features of small bowel obstruction
  • Ectopic gall stone - usually in the right iliac fossa

Plain X-rays show air-fluid levels consistent with a small bowel obstruction and pneumobilia can be visualized on CT imaging.

Management: Predominantly surgical management by an explorative laparotomy to relieve the bowel obstruction. The stone is milked away from the site of impacted and then crushed or removed. 

 

Other options: Adhesive intestinal obstruction (Option B) results mostly after any abdominal surgery or any cause for peritoneal irritation, the features are consistent with bowel obstruction but there is no pneumobilia.

Ischaemic colitis (Option B) is usually diagnosed on contrast-enhanced CT abdomen where there may be bowel wall thickening, signs of vascular insufficiency, and pericolic fluid or fat stranding.

Diverticulitis (Option D) is also diagnosed on CT abdomen showing bright bowel outpouching, which may be complicated by infection and abscess formation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady complains of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning. What is the route of administration of the first non-azole drug approved to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of thick curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning are suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. The first and the only non-azole antifungal approved for the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis is Ibrexafungerp. The route of administration of this drug is oral.

Ibrexafungerp is a triterpenoid antifungal agent that acts by inhibiting glucan synthase. Glucan synthase is an enzyme involved in the formation of 1,3-beta-D-glucan which is an essential component of the fungal cell wall.

The recommended dosage is 600 mg orally as 2 divided doses 12 hrs apart. Contraindications include pregnancy and hypersensitivity to ibrexafungerp. The most frequent adverse reactions are diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, dizziness, and vomiting.

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in:

choices.text: Prevention of Seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia
Prevention of RDS in premature baby

questions.solution:
Magnesium sulphate has no role in the prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a premature baby.

Magnesium sulfate administered parenterally is an effective anticonvulsant that avoids producing central nervous system depression. It may be given intravenously by continuous infusion or intramuscularly by intermittent injection. Magnesium sulfate has a neuroprotective effect

It reduces contractility of the uterus and can be used as a tocolytic.

MgSo4 is a membrane stabilizer and a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach. Very low-birthweight neonates whose mothers were treated with magnesium sulfate for preterm labor or preeclampsia were found to have a reduced incidence of cerebral palsy at 3 years.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a history of sexual assault followed by amenorrhea. Her urine pregnancy test was positive. Which of the following is the most likely maturation index of her vaginal epithelium?
questions.solution:
The most likely maturation index of vaginal epithelium in a pregnant woman is 0/95/5.

The maturation index is also known as the karyopyknotic index. It is the ratio of mature squamous (superficial) cells to the intermediate and parabasal cells, expressed in percentage. It is expressed in three numbers expressing each of these cell types in percentages, in the format of parabasal cells/intermediate cells/superficial cells. 

Parabasal cells are round small and basophilic. Intermediate cells are transparent and basophilic. Superficial cells are thin, large, and acidophilic.

A significant shift in the maturation index can be seen from birth to menopause. It correlates with the hormonal status of the vaginal epithelium. In the proliferative (estrogenic) phase of the menstrual cycle, the ratio of superficial cells is more than 25 percent. And the ratio is low in the secretory (progestational) phase of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy. Parabasal cells are predominant in the postmenopausal phase.

In pregnancy, the most likely maturation index is 0/95/5. During pregnancy, if the ratio of superficial cells is more than 10 percent it denotes the progesterone deficiency.

The most likely shift of the maturation index from birth to menopause is:

 Stage           Maturation index
(parabasal/intermediate/superficial)
At birth  0/95/5
Childhood    80/20/0
Reproductive period
preovulatory  0/40/60
mild secretory  0/70/30
pregnancy  0/95/5
postpartum    100/0/0   
Postmenopausal  100/0/0

questions.text: False statement regarding Down’s syndrome is?

choices.text: Most common cardiovascular lesion is endocardial cushion defect
It is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability
Most common cause of intestinal obstruction is intussusception
AML is more common during first 3 years of life

questions.solution:
Most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down’s syndrome is duodenal atresia. 

Clinical features of Down’s syndrome: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere) 

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly 
  • Congenital heart disease 
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum 
  • Protruding tongue 
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth 
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots 
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge 
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic 
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure) 
  • Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes 

Note: 

  • Down’s syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability. 
  • Most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign). 
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukemias, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).  
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life. 
  • Most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML).  
  • Most common hematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM). 
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. He complains of pain in his left elbow. Examination reveals tenderness and swelling over his left elbow. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true with respect to this condition?

choices.text: Vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery
Ulnar nerve  is most commonly injured in the extension-type
Almost all injuries are of the flexion-type
Cubitus valgus is the most common angular deformity

questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray showing posterior fat pad sign are suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus where vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

It is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. Gartland classification is used for the classification of supracondylar fractures and is of four types.

On examination:

There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there are blood vessel involvement.

Cubitus Varus deformity:

Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. The static deformities of cubitus varus with respect to the distal fragment are :

  • Posterior displacement
  • Horizontal rotation
  • Coronal tilt.

Treatment: 

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better modalities of treatment.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates.

Other options:

Option B: The most common nerve injury in extension-type supracondylar fractures is actually to the median nerve, not the ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve is more commonly injured in flexion-type fractures.

Option C: The majority of supracondylar fractures in children are of the extension-type, not the flexion-type. 

Option D: The most common angular deformity after a supracondylar fracture is cubitus varus (Gunstock deformity), not cubitus valgus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, and an eFAST was performed. What is the additional view incorporated to this imaging modality?
questions.solution:
Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is extended into the thoracic cavities and peri­cardium (eFAST), where anterior pleural views are incorporated. It is a technique in which ultrasonography is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity. 

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

The patient is placed in a supine position. With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer the following regions are scanned :

  • Subxiphoid transverse view(also called subcostal view or pericardial view)
  • Right upper quadrant view (also called right flank view or perihepatic view)
  • Left upper quadrant view (also called Perisplenic or left flank view) 
  • Suprapubic view or Pelvic view

An extended FAST or eFAST scan incorporates the Anterior pleural views to assess the anterior thorax.

Drawbacks of FAST:

  • Does not reliably detect less than 100 mL of free blood
  • Does not directly identify hollow viscus injury or penetrating trauma
  • Often requires supplementing with other investigations
  • Does not assess the retroperitoneum

questions.text: Which of the following is not a likely symptom of a panic attack?
questions.solution:
A suicide attempt is not a likely symptom of a panic attack.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that may last from minutes to hours. Recurrent panic attacks are termed panic disorders.

Panic attacks can occur in other disorders, particu­larly in specific phobias, social phobias, and post-traumatic stress disorder. 

Unexpected panic attacks occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable situational trigger. Attacks in patients with social and specific pho­bias are usually expected in response to a specific stimulus.

Some panic attacks do not fit into unexpected or expected attacks, and these attacks are referred to as situationally predisposed panic attacks. They may or may not occur on exposure to a specific trigger, or may occur immediately after exposure or after a considerable period of time.

Four or more of the following should be present to label it a panic attack:

  • Palpitations, pounding heart, or accelerated heart rate.
  • Sweating.
  • Trembling or shaking
  • Sensations of shortness of breath or smothering
  • Feelings of choking
  • Chest pain or discomfort.
  • Nausea or abdominal distress.
  • Dizziness, unsteady, light-headed, or faint
  • Chills or heat sensations
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (feeling detached from oneself)
  • Fear of losing control or "going crazy."
  • Fear of dying

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.
Occur spontaneously without overt precipitants.
 
They often avoid situations/ places in which panic attacks have occurred.

Treatment is with benzodiazepines or SSRI/ SNRI and cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific to social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: Inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient with pneumothorax is ______
questions.solution:
Inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient with pneumothorax is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has the potential to expand air containing cavities as it can diffuse into and accumulate in them. Hence it should be avoided in patients with pneumothorax.

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • N2O although insoluble when compared to volatile agents, it is about 35 times more soluble than O2 and N2 
  • Rapid uptake of nitrous oxide diminishes the volume to the alveolus
  • This 'concentrates' the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus

Second gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction

Diffusion hypoxia

  • aka Fink's effect
  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia.
  • Avoided by administering 100% oxygen for about 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous in gas-filled spaces

  • N2O diffuses into a gas-filled cavity more rapidly than the air (principally nitrogen) diffuses out
  • This increases the pressure within the cavity if the volume of the cavity is rigid.
  • Hence N2O is contraindicated in:
    • Venous or arterial air embolism
    • Acute intestinal obstruction
    • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
    • Pulmonary air cysts
    • Intraocular air bubbles
    • Tympanic membrane grafting

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

Inhalational agent of choice  
1. Induction  Sevoflurane
2. Day care surgery Sevoflurane(preferred)/Desflurane
3. Elderly  Desflurane
4. Cardiac disease Isoflurane
5. Renal disease Desflurane
6. Liver disease  Sevoflurane
7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane(preferred)/Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane
9. Obese patients Desflurane

Most potent      

 Methoxyflurane>Halothane 

Least potent     

 Nitrous oxide>Desflurane 

Most epileptogenic  

 Enflurane

Most nephrotoxic  

 Methoxyflurane 

Most hepatotoxic 

 Halothane

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to your clinic with complaints of itchy rashes on his body for the past two weeks. He lives in a school hostel room. After obtaining a thorough history, you perform microscopy of the skin scraping from the interdigital web space, findings of which are shown below. Which of the following statement/s are incorrect regarding the suspected diagnosis?

1- The burrows are made by the gravid female mite 

2- The pruritus is due to an immune reaction to the excreta of the mite 

3- It typically involves the face, scalp, palms, and soles

4- It can be treated using topical permethrin 

5- Treatment of close contacts is not required
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of scabies. It is caused by the itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. Among the given options, statements 3 and 5 are incorrect. 

The pathogenesis of scabies includes infestation by Sarcoptes scabiei. They are obligate human ectoparasites as they die within a day if they do not find a suitable host. On finding a suitable host, gravid female mites burrow into the superficial epidermis and lay eggs. These eggs hatch into six-legged larvae that evolve into eight-legged nymphs. The symptoms such as rash and itching are due to immune reactions to the excretory products of the mites in the skin. 

Scabies is transmitted by direct skin-to-skin contact and less frequently via contaminated clothes and bedding. They are seen more commonly in overcrowded areas, hostels, and schools, especially in unhygienic environments. 

Clinically, these patients present with superficial excoriated papules or vesicles that are intensely pruritic. They are usually present on the volar surface of the wrists, interdigital spaces, penis, scrotum, navel, and skin folds and creases in the axillae, buttocks, and thigh regions. Burrows may be visualized in the superficial dermis in the abovementioned regions. Pruritis is typically intense and increases after showers and during the night. 

Immunodeficient individuals may develop a widespread form known as crusted scabies or Norwegian scabies. Although they may be infected with thousands of mites, they might not have intense pruritis due to muted immune response. Characteristic burrows are typically absent, instead, they present with thick keratotic crusts and scaly plaques. 

Diagnosis is established considering the characteristic history and by dermatoscopic imaging or microscopy of the skin scrapings or cellophane tape lifted from lesions. 

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice. It is preferred over 1% lindane preparation and ivermectin. These preparations are applied once, all over the body below the jawline, following a bath. It should be washed off with soap and water after 8-14 hours. Oral ivermectin may be given in the dose of 200 μg/kg once in healthy adults and in two doses one-two weeks apart in patients with widespread, crusted scabies. Supportive treatment with antihistamines, calamine lotion, and topical steroids may help treat the associated pruritis. 

It is imperative to treat close contacts simultaneously and wash bedding and clothing to prevent reinfestations.

questions.text: A radiation oncologist uses radiotherapy as part of the treatment protocol for various tumors. This treatment modality is found to be least effective in which among the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is least effective in melanoma as it is a highly radioresistant tumor.

Apoptosis occurs in response to radiation in some but not all cells. No meaningful apoptosis occurs in very radioresistant tumors like melanoma and glioblastoma.

Seminoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor and hence radiotherapy is commonly used for treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
